roanoke.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website for The Roanoke Times, a daily newspaper serving Roanoke, Virginia, and the southwestern portion of the state.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The Roanoke Times is owned by BH Media Group Inc., a subsidiary of publicly traded, Omaha, Nebraska-based Berkshire Hathaway, which is run by billionaire investor Warren Buffett. BH Media Group owns more than 30 daily newspapers, including its flagship publication, The Omaha World-Herald. It also owns more than 70 weekly newspapers and other printed publications in the United States, as well as one television station. In July 2018, Lee Enterprises, a publicly traded newspaper chain that owns more than 40 daily newspapers across the country, began managing operations for BH Media’s newspapers under a partnership announced by the two companies.

BH Media generates revenue from advertising and subscriptions for its printed publications and digital products. Its publications have won numerous awards for their journalism, including a Pulitzer Prize in 2018.

Content

The site offers originally reported news on Roanoke and Virginia, including dedicated sections on crime, politics, and education, among other topics. Virginia-based political coverage is featured  on a Politics page and on a blog called the Blue Ridge Caucus. A page called In Depth packages series and podcasts on a broad range of topics. The sports section includes extensive coverage of nearby Virginia Tech, the University of Virginia, and minor league hockey and baseball teams, as well as syndicated coverage of major sports.

Other sections focus on opinion, business, entertainment and weather. National and internatinal news comes from The Associated Press

Credibility

Articles on roanokenews.com are fact-based and supported by original reporting and external sources. Headlines accurately reflect content.

A page titled Professional Standards and Content Policies offers an extensive mission statement asserting the need for integrity and serving the public interest.  It also includes detailed explanations of internal policies prohibiting reporters’ relationships with news sources, business involvement related to stories they cover, outside work that would compromise their objectivity, and personal social media use.

The site posts a correction policy and has a form for users to request corrections. Corrected stories are posted with a box at the top of the story, including a note indicating that a correction has been made,

The Roanoke Times won nine first-place awards in 2018 at the Virginia Press Association awards, including for editorial writing on the plight of local coal fields, and for general news writing for a series on the 10th anniversary of the Virginia Tech mass shooting.

Transparency

The website’s Contact page indicates its ownership by subsidiary BK Media and parent Berkshire Hathaway. The page lists news managers and content creators for the newspaper as well as staff dedicated to the website, and lists both phone numbers and email addresses for all editorial staff. Most names are linked to brief biographies. Reporters’ bylines have links to their contact information and social media accounts.

Opinion pieces are posted in a separate section, and identified in their headlines as either editorials or commentary by guest editorial writers. The section also includes a form for submitting letters to the editor. Advertisements are clearly distinguished from editorial content, and sponsored content in labeled as such.

.

History

The newspaper began publication in 1886 as The Roanoke Daily Times. In 1991, it became known as The Roanoke Times & World-News when its then-owner stopped publication of the afternoon World-News. The paper dropped the latter part of its name in 1995.

The Roanoke Times has won praise for its coverage of several significant national stories in recent years. Chief among these were a 2007 mass shooting at Virginia Tech that killed 32 people, and the 2015 on-air murders of two journalists at a Roanoke TV station, CBS affiliate WDBJ.

BK Media bought the paper in 2013 from Landmark Communications, which had owned it since 1969.
